title: Bump pylint from 2.13.5 to 2.13.7 in /kanidm_rlm_python

labels.name: dependencies
labels.description: Pull requests that update a dependency file

body:
Bumps [pylint](https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint) from 2.13.5 to 2.13.7.
Changelog

Sourced from pylint's changelog.

What's New in Pylint 2.13.7?

Release date: 2022-04-20

  • Fix a crash caused by using the new config from 2.14.0 in 2.13.x code.

    Closes #6408

What's New in Pylint 2.13.6?

Release date: 2022-04-20

  • Fix a crash in the unsupported-membership-test checker when assigning multiple constants to class attributes including __iter__ via unpacking.

    Closes #6366

  • Asterisks are no longer required in Sphinx and Google style parameter documentation for missing-param-doc and are parsed correctly.

    Closes #5815 Closes #5406

  • Fixed a false positive for unused-variable when a builtin specified in --additional-builtins is given a type annotation.

    Closes #6388

  • Fixed an AstroidError in 2.13.0 raised by the duplicate-code checker with ignore-imports or ignore-signatures enabled.

    Closes #6301

Commits
  • 3b2fbae Bump pylint to 2.13.7, update changelog
  • 106f0af Fix 'object has no attribute additional_builtins' (#6410)
  • 19d660e Bump pylint to 2.13.6, update changelog
  • 1310f55 [pre-commit.ci] pre-commit autoupdate to fix the black issue
  • 1622eae Upgrade astroid to 2.11.3 (#6398)
  • ddca4dd Prevent false positive undefined-variable for user-specified builtins given...
  • 7231dd5 Fix a crash in the unsupported-membership-test checker involving tuple un...
  • 664049c Fix AstroidError in similarity checker with imports/signatures ignored (#6357)
  • cca0d02 Suppress useless-super-delegation if return type changed (#5822) (#6141)
  • 709fc58 Handle asterisks better in Sphinx and Google style docstrings
  • See full diff in compare view

[![Dependabot compatibility score](https://dependabot-badges.githubapp.com/badges/compatibility_score?dependency-name=pylint&package-manager=pip&previous-version=2.13.5&new-version=2.13.7)](https://docs.github.com/en/github/managing-security-vulnerabilities/about-dependabot-security-updates#about-compatibility-scores) Dependabot will resolve any conflicts with this PR as long as you don't alter it yourself. You can also trigger a rebase manually by commenting `@dependabot rebase`. [//]: # (dependabot-automerge-start) [//]: # (dependabot-automerge-end) ---
Dependabot commands and options
You can trigger Dependabot actions by commenting on this PR: - `@dependabot rebase` will rebase this PR - `@dependabot recreate` will recreate this PR, overwriting any edits that have been made to it - `@dependabot merge` will merge this PR after your CI passes on it - `@dependabot squash and merge` will squash and merge this PR after your CI passes on it - `@dependabot cancel merge` will cancel a previously requested merge and block automerging - `@dependabot reopen` will reopen this PR if it is closed - `@dependabot close` will close this PR and stop Dependabot recreating it. You can achieve the same result by closing it manually - `@dependabot ignore this major version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this major version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this minor version` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this minor version (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself) - `@dependabot ignore this dependency` will close this PR and stop Dependabot creating any more for this dependency (unless you reopen the PR or upgrade to it yourself)

body:

title: Add a new ACP and group allowing self-service mail updates
body:
This adds a new "idm_people_self_write_mail_priv" group which follows
the existing canned group+acp format closely.

This also adds a test for the functionality

See the discussion in #648 for a bit more background

- [x] cargo fmt has been run
- [x] cargo clippy has been run
- [x] cargo test has been run and passes
- [ ] ~book chapter included (if relevant)~ | minor doc section added where "people" accounts are mentioned
- [ ] ~design document included (if relevant)~

------

As some meta-commentary, the acp/group code was straightforward enough to make this change feel pretty easy, woo! It's very clearly meant as an intermediate state, but even so it wasn't hard to work with.

The `_UUID` consts, presumably to reserve IDs, did feel a little weird. They weren't actually referenced anywhere, like inline in ACP poicies (rather the UUID itself was copy-pasted), and they don't actually validate uniqueness on their own, other than by having one file to search through.

I'm curious, is the intent just a place to grep for IDs in? Is there a different plan for those consts eventually?

title: Add 'account person set' command
body:
This command allows a user to modify, say, their legal name in a
self-service fashion.

This wasn't possible before by default since the 'extend' operation
required additional ACPs in order to operate which not every user would
have, specifically the ability to add a "class" of "person" to the account.

The new "person set" api is compatible with the default self_write ACP,
and so allows self-service modification.

See #648 for more info.

I didn't tackle improving the `account` vs `self` splitup of commands yet. I think I can reasonably do that as a separate PR, and that'll make things easier for me, and for reviewers. I would like to come back to tackle that in a followup.

Manual testing done:

```
$ kanidm account create test6 "user" -D idm_admin
$ kanidm account get test6 -D idm_admin
class: account
class: object
displayname: user
name: test6
spn: test6@example.com
uuid: b02fd2f3-36ec-4ed0-aa27-e7755d451731

$ kanidm account person set test6 --legalname "test" -D test6
2022-04-01T23:52:27.859834Z ERROR kanidm_cli::account: Error -> Http(400, Some(SchemaViolation(InvalidAttribute("legalname"))), "5f40e0f8-4253-40eb-9dd3-b4fbf403f46c")

$ kanidm account person extend test6 --legalname "initial name" -D idm_admin
$ kanidm account get test6 -D test6
class: account
class: object
class: person
displayname: user
legalname: initial name
name: test6
primary_credential: primary
spn: test6@example.com
uuid: b02fd2f3-36ec-4ed0-aa27-e7755d451731

$ kanidm account person set test6 --legalname "updated name" -D test6
$ kanidm account get test6 -D test6
class: account
class: object
class: person
displayname: user
legalname: updated name
name: test6
primary_credential: primary
spn: test6@example.com
uuid: b02fd2f3-36ec-4ed0-aa27-e7755d451731
```


- [x] cargo fmt has been run
- [x] cargo clippy has been run
- [x] cargo test has been run and passes
- [ ] ~book chapter included (if relevant)~ I added a section, not a full chapter
- [ ] ~design document included (if relevant)~ Probably not relevant

title: Display errors when cli operations fail
body:
```
# before this change
$ kanidm account delete does-not-exist -D admin
$ # no output; exit status 0

# after this change
$ kanidm account delete does-not-exist -D admin                                                                                                                                        5s
2022-04-01T21:34:51.857904Z ERROR kanidm_cli::account: Error -> Http(404, Some(NoMatchingEntries), "32a34959-2cc9-449e-b9c3-dff8d30a736b")
```

This fixes a regression, introduced in #659, in the CLI's default output.
Since 404 & 403 errors don't trigger any logs further down the stack,
they'd exit eerily silently with the default cli loglevel.

- [x] cargo fmt has been run
- [x] cargo clippy has been run
- [x] cargo test has been run and passes
- [ ] ~book chapter included (if relevant)~ not relevant
- [ ] ~design document included (if relevant)~ not relevant

title: Use pkg-config to link against pam
body:
Some distros, such as nixos, require more than just '-lpam' to locate
the library. Adding a naive pkg-config invocation to the pam FFI
crate allows pam_kanidm to build on my system, where before this change it did not.

title: 106 auth concurrency
body:
Fixes #106 - Implements concurrency in authentication. This exposed a few minor issues in how we were handling async in auth functions, which will be important later once we implement remote-auth for trusts and read-only systems. This will improve auth throughput in high load situations, while retaining all the previous guarantees of softlocking over credentials. 

This was done in preparation for multi-credential auth and credential reset workflows to help me get a refresh of how this all fits together ^^;

title: Change how domain names are handled in our configuration.
body:
Fixes #623 - Improve domain name handling on server startup. Rather than starting with a default domain and expecting a rename, we make the domain name a config value in server.toml. When the server starts up, we use this initially to create the first domain name. When a domain rename is requested, we read the value from server.toml (and skip the origin check by not starting the idms layer).  Finally, this adds a config tester that can check if the server "would start" with this configuration. As always, book chapters have been updated too :)

title: Check before rename for #622
body:
This checks you're actually changing the domain name and quits if it's not. Still pretty noisy from a logging perspective because it has to boot up the QueryServer, but it's quick (0.7s in my testing)

In the case of a non-change, you'll get:

    00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000 2021-11-29T23:13:56.450842+00:00 INFO     💬 [admin.info]: Domain name not changing, stopping.

And a return code of `125` (ECANCELED/Operation Cancelled) to note the change wasn't made.

old error:

> Error during authentication phase: Err(Transport(reqwest::Error { kind: Request, url: Url { scheme: "https", cannot_be_a_base: false, username: "", password: None, host: Some(Domain("kanidm.example.com")), port: None, path: "/v1/auth", query: None, fragment: None }, source: hyper::Error(Connect, ConnectError("tcp connect error", Os { code: 111, kind: ConnectionRefused, message: "Connection refused" })) }))


new error looks like:

> [2021-08-07T12:39:25Z ERROR kanidm_ssh_authorizedkeys_direct] Failed to connect to kanidm server: error sending request for url (https://kanidm.example.com/v1/auth): error trying to connect: tcp connect error: Connection refused (os error 61)

title: 468 valueset
body:
Relates #468 - this is stage one of converting to a proper ValueSet type inside of Entry. This replaces the direct usage of BTreeSet with ValueSet in entry, and asserts that all the current tests and behaviours pass. The intent is that by separating this with this layer, we now know what interfaces are required in ValueSet when we begin the conversation to a properly typed internal.

title: Auto-publishing the book and rustdoc.
body: I guess I licked it? This adds Github Action magic to publish both the book and the `rustdoc` for kanidm. @Firstyear this'll need some tweaking on the project settings once it's merged. - Go to https://github.com/kanidm/kanidm/settings/pages - Set the source branch to `gh-pages` and hit `Save` - Enforce HTTPS because TLS is good. It'll publish the book at https://kanidm.github.io/kanidm/ and `rustdoc` at https://kanidm.github.io/kanidm/rustdoc/kanidm/ # Screenshot of my test settings below:

title: Add wal checkpointing to startup/vacuum
